title: Previous attachments can be referenced when creating a new report

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hello
When user upload file in comment to report, user can find file ID by two ways:
1. In preview mode - In response to POST method `https://hackerone.com/attachments` , answer will be something like this:
-`{"id":84577,"name":"mytestfile.png","size":32397}` where file_ID = 84577 (for example)
2. If user post comment - At link to hackerone-attachments.s3.amazonaws.com, where file_ID is part of the link 
.../production/000/084/579/2b912875c3e8856c300dad535b732500f3c42c25/...
In this case file_ID = 84579

When user post new report to some company on page:
https://hackerone.com/[some_company]/reports/new
in this page user's draft autosave by POST request:
https://hackerone.com/security/reports/draft_sync

So if user post comment to report_1 and get file_ID_1, then he go to post new report to another company
and generate autosave POST request by himself and change file_ID_new_report to  file_ID_1
For example:
`report%5Btitle%5D=&report%5Bvulnerability_information%5D=Ffile_ID_1&report%5Battachment_ids%5D%5B%5D= file_ID_1&report%5Bforce%5D=false`
And, as you can see, set in param `vulnerability_information` Ffile_ID_1 (for example F84577)

Then user reload page with new report (F5), there two issues:
1. After Markdown parse he have direct link to file in comment (in our case file_ID_1 ): where comment to another report and another company.
I think it's not so critical, but same experiment with file, which uploaded directly in initial report_1, is fail.
2. More Strange - file_1 in comment to report_1 is deleted! No more link to file in this comment.

My same experiment with file uploaded by another user (I make test account : @dkusliy_test) also is fail.
Luckily)) 

Thanks and Best!
vulnerability_information_html:
Hello
When user upload file in comment to report, user can find file ID by two ways:

  1. In preview mode - In response to POST method https://hackerone.com/attachments , answer will be something like this: -{"id":84577,"name":"mytestfile.png","size":32397} where file_ID = 84577 (for example)
  2. If user post comment - At link to hackerone-attachments.s3.amazonaws.com, where file_ID is part of the link .../production/000/084/579/2b912875c3e8856c300dad535b732500f3c42c25/... In this case file_ID = 84579

When user post new report to some company on page:
https://hackerone.com/%5Bsome_company%5D/reports/new
in this page user's draft autosave by POST request:
https://hackerone.com/security/reports/draft_sync

So if user post comment to report_1 and get file_ID_1, then he go to post new report to another company
and generate autosave POST request by himself and change file_ID_new_report to file_ID_1
For example:
report%5Btitle%5D=&report%5Bvulnerability_information%5D=Ffile_ID_1&report%5Battachment_ids%5D%5B%5D= file_ID_1&report%5Bforce%5D=false
And, as you can see, set in param vulnerability_information Ffile_ID_1 (for example F84577)

Then user reload page with new report (F5), there two issues:

  1. After Markdown parse he have direct link to file in comment (in our case file_ID_1 ): where comment to another report and another company. I think it's not so critical, but same experiment with file, which uploaded directly in initial report_1, is fail.
  2. More Strange - file_1 in comment to report_1 is deleted! No more link to file in this comment.

My same experiment with file uploaded by another user (I make test account : @dkusliy_test) also is fail.
Luckily))

Thanks and Best!

activities.message: Based on your initial description, there do not appear to be any security implications as a direct result of this behavior. If you disagree, please reply with additional information describing your reasoning. Including a working proof-of-concept can be incredibly helpful in our assessment of these claims.

Thank's. Of course, the attack vector is little applicable.
Otherwise, we can't edit text in comment after some time. This bug allow user delete attached files. User can manipulate attached files for fraud and "Request Mediation",  that may harm the reputation of HackerOne, for example...

activities.message: Hi @dkusliy,  We have pushed out a fix for the stated issue.  However, I do not believe this qualifies as a security vulnerability as there is no clear way this can be exploited.  The user is only allowed to access his or her own attachments, and by altering his or her own reports is only hurting themselves I believe.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @dkusliy, We have pushed out a fix for the stated issue. However, I do not believe this qualifies as a security vulnerability as there is no clear way this can be exploited. The user is only allowed to access his or her own attachments, and by altering his or her own reports is only hurting themselves I believe.

activities.message:
I can't reproduce this issue. Look's like fixed.

However, I think this issue can qualifies as [OWASP TOP-10 A7](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10_2013-A7-Missing_Function_Level_Access_Control). 

In **Application Specific** we can see _Could anonymous users access private functionality or regular users a privileged function_
In my case regular user can't delete attached files, but this issue can allow this function to him.

What do you think about this?
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
Hi @dkusliy,

As stated earlier, the behavior you described was limited to attachments that were owned by the user directly.  There was no information being accessed by the user to which they did not already have access.  It would be similar to the user editing the report directly to remove the attachment.  In this case, it is a functional bug, but is not a security issue.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @dkusliy,

As stated earlier, the behavior you described was limited to attachments that were owned by the user directly. There was no information being accessed by the user to which they did not already have access. It would be similar to the user editing the report directly to remove the attachment. In this case, it is a functional bug, but is not a security issue.

activities.message: Ok, thx.
activities.markdown_message: Ok, thx.

activities.message:
Hi, little update... if you do not mind..
If I decide to attach file to comment, but then change my mind. I still can access to file through generate new report and modify autosave draft.

Steps:
1. Upload file to comment
2. Get file ID from response of `https://hackerone.com/attachments`
3. Delete file by clicking [X]
4. Do the same tricks with draft sync when post new report, which describe in  initial description. 
5. User have direct link to file, that was previously deleted

This can lead to an increase the volume of file storage, for example.
Thanks
activities.markdown_message:
Hi, little update... if you do not mind..
If I decide to attach file to comment, but then change my mind. I still can access to file through generate new report and modify autosave draft.

Steps:

  1. Upload file to comment
  2. Get file ID from response of https://hackerone.com/attachments
  3. Delete file by clicking [X]
  4. Do the same tricks with draft sync when post new report, which describe in initial description.
  5. User have direct link to file, that was previously deleted

This can lead to an increase the volume of file storage, for example.
Thanks

activities.message: Or attacker can create hidden files storage for their own purposes.

activities.message:
And attacker's files will be always hidden . And only attacker know way to access his/her files. This files hidden in any reports and comments. Attacker must only remember file ID and file name, for example. (create a little databases) .

I think that files that not belong to any report or comment must be deleted or there wasn't any ways to get direct link to file.

Thanks

activities.message: @dkusliy you have a valid point. Closing this as a duplicate of #123615.
activities.markdown_message: @dkusliy you have a valid point. Closing this as a duplicate of #123615.

activities.message:
Thanks. 
But I think this is not correct way to close my report as duplicate. 
First of all, fix to report 123615 was pushed out on Mar 25th, but my report was submitted on Apr 11th. So there was not fully fix for a problem with attached files. 
Secondly, the report 123615 was just about attached files to initial description of report. My report was about attached files in comment. 
Third, on Apr 21st I posted an additional update. According to this update, attacker can use HackerOne's file storage to keep his malicious files. This files will be hidden in any reports and comments.

Thanks!

activities.message:
Hello, 
thank you for answer!

But I still can not understand you. report #123615 was eligible for bounty. Report #129773 you try to close as N/A. Issue in report #123615 was fixed, but in report #129773 issue was reproduce again (with some updates). If it is duplicate, issue will not reproduce after fix report #123615.

In report #123615, @fern written on Mar 17th: 
>"I've confirmed that this only works when the reports belong to the same user (you)".

Yes, both issues in reports #123615 #129773 work only with user's attachments.

I understood you when you close my report ( #129773 ) as N/A, firstly. I agreed that this not security bug, rather functionality. But after sometime spent, report #123615 was public disclose with bounty. 
I will understand you if both report #123615 #129773 was closed as N/A, but not one is N/A, other with reward.

Thanks!

In report #123615, @fern written on Mar 17th:

I understood you when you close my report ( #129773 ) as N/A, firstly. I agreed that this not security bug, rather functionality. But after sometime spent, report #123615 was public disclose with bounty.

activities.message:
Hello @dkusliy, 

As far as we can tell, #123615 is a vulnerability because it includes redacting information. That is what we awarded for. We did not consider the scenario in his follow up comments to be a vulnerability - that is in line with our decision regarding your report. Summing up: 
- We cared about the part in his report that allowed users to delete attachments after submission
- We don't care about unused attachments. This is not an immediate concern for us, and we allow this behaviour because we allow users to have reference ids at the time of writing their comment. 

I hope this clears things up.
activities.markdown_message:
Hello @dkusliy,

As far as we can tell, #123615 is a vulnerability because it includes redacting information. That is what we awarded for. We did not consider the scenario in his follow up comments to be a vulnerability - that is in line with our decision regarding your report. Summing up:

  • We cared about the part in his report that allowed users to delete attachments after submission
  • We don't care about unused attachments. This is not an immediate concern for us, and we allow this behaviour because we allow users to have reference ids at the time of writing their comment.

I hope this clears things up.

activities.message:
Ok, thank's!
But my report not only about unused attachments. User can post report to some team. Without any attachments. Then post first comment with attachments, for example, when team request for additional information. And then scenario like in report #123615. 
Delete attachments in comment was described in my initial report.

Thank you!

activities.message:
Hi @kusl - 

At HackerOne we value transparency. Misunderstanding happens, miscommunication happens, and mistakes happen - and we value them a lot because we learn and grow from them. Therefore we don't mind, and strongly encourage public disclosure, even if some of them might contain uncomfortable conversations. 

I hope that you're standing with us on our core values. Thanks for participating in our bounty program and happy hunting!

-Pei
